section.name: Quick Install for Testing, Documentation and Tutorial

ul.li: Download Tiles binary distribution
Unzip distribution
Create a new web application containing Tiles and all dependencies.
Create one or more Tiles Definitions XML files in the /WEB-INF directory of the new application.
Deploy the new application.

section.name: Prerequisite Software
section.p: A full listing of Tiles dependencies can be found here. This sections discusses those items that are required at runtime.

ul.li: Java Development Kit - Tiles will work with any compliant JDK version 1.3 or later.

Servlet Container - Tiles supports any servlet container that is compatible with the Servlet API Specification, version 2.2 or later, and the JavaServer Pages (JSP) Specification, version 1.1 or later. One popular choice is to download Apache's Tomcat

XML Parser - Tiles requires the presence of an XML parser that is compatible with the Java API for XML Parsing (JAXP) specification, 1.1 or later. If you are using JDK 1.4 or later, an XML parser is provided with the JDK. Otherwise you can download and install the JAXP reference implementation or any other JAXP compliant parser, such as Xerces.

Jakarta Commons Packages - Tiles utilizes several packages from the Jakarta Commons Project. See the Dependencies List for specific versions. These dependencies can be downloaded using the Maven build process.

Struts Framework - If you are planning to use Tiles with Struts, you should download and install Struts from
Apache Struts Project. If you have acquired Tiles with the Struts distribution, you don't need to install it again. Tiles can run without Struts. In this case you lose some features.

section.name: Install A Tiles Binary Distribution
section.p: First, download a binary distribution of Tiles, currently distributed with the Struts Framework.

Unpack the Tiles binary distribution into a convenient directory. (If you build Tiles from the source distribution, the result of the build will already be an unpacked binary distribution for you). The distribution consists of the following contents:

ul.li: struts-tiles-VERSION.jar - This JAR file contains all of the Java classes included in Tiles. It should be copied into the WEB-INF/lib directory of your web application. WARNING - If you are going to be hosting multiple tiles based applications on the same servlet container, you will be tempted to place the JAR file into the shared repository supported by your container. Be advised that this will likely cause you to encounter ClassNotFoundException problems unless all of your application classes are stored in the shared repository.

section.p: To use Tiles in your own application, you will need to follow these steps:

ul.li: Copy the prerequisite Jar files into the WEB-INF/lib directory of your web application.

If you want to use the definitions configuration file, you need to initialize the definitions factory. This can be done as follows:
Using Tiles With Struts - Modify the WEB-INF/web.xml file for your web application to use a <servlet> that responds to Struts actions. You will need to configure the Tiles Plugin and the Tiles Request Processor to allow Struts to respond to Tiles-based Action Forwards. Below is a sample Tiles Plugin configuration.
<plug-in className="org.apache.struts.tiles.TilesPlugin"> <set-property property="definitions-config" value="/WEB-INF/tiles-defs.xml"/> </plug-in>
Using Tiles Without Struts - If you don't want to use Struts, use the org.apache.struts.tiles.TilesServlet as the servlet.
Create a configuration file for definitions. Its name must match the one provided before in WEB-INF/web.xml. Several comma separated names can be provided.

Modify the WEB-INF/web.xml file of your web application to include the following tag library declarations: Note that this step is not necessary in a Servlet 2.3/2.4 envrironment.
<taglib> <taglib-uri>/WEB-INF/tiles.tld</taglib-uri> <taglib-location>/WEB-INF/tiles.tld</taglib-location> </taglib>

At the top of each JSP page that will use the Tiles custom tags, add line(s) declaring the Tiles custom tag libraries used on this particular page, like this:
<%@ taglib uri="/WEB-INF/tiles.tld" prefix="tiles" %>

For Servlet 2.3/2.4 applications replace the above taglib reference with the following:
<%@ taglib uri="http://struts.apache.org/tags-tiles" prefix="tiles" %>
When compiling the Java classes that comprise your application, be sure to include the tiles.jar and commons-*.jar files (copied earlier) on the CLASSPATH that is submitted to the compiler.
You should use a tiles.jar build with Struts1.0.x.
If you have downloaded a Tiles version build with Struts1.0.x, you already have it.
You should also initialize a TilesRequestProcessor.

To do so, add following lines in your struts-config.xml file :
<controller processorClass="org.apache.struts.tiles.TilesRequestProcessor"> </controller>

section.name: Installing Tiles with your servlet container
section.p: WARNING - Do NOT add tiles.jar to the classpath of your servlet container in an attempt to avoid placing it in the /WEB-INF/lib directory of each individual web app! Doing so will cause problems with ClassNotFoundException exceptions.
For most containers, you need only to:

ul.li: Copy the WAR files in your Tiles /webapp directory to your containers webapps directory.
In some cases, you may need to restart your container if it is running.

section.p:
For the status of additional containers, please refer to the
Struts installation page).

section.name: Building Tiles From Source
section.p: First, download a source distribution of Tiles. See here for more info. (Note: Tiles can also be found here.) You can then use the included Maven build script to build Tiles.
